values.description:
And an invocation in start_sim.bash (router side)

This is the mail script:

```
#!python
#!/usr/bin/python

#
# Send a mail to to drcsim-support@osrfoundation.com
# postfix should be installed on your system

try:
    import sys
    import smtplib
    import datetime

    _from = sys.argv[1]
    subject = sys.argv[2]

    text = "at %s UTC" % datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    server = smtplib.SMTP('localhost')
    server.set_debuglevel(1)

    fromaddr = "%s@osrfoundation.org" % _from
    toaddr_list = ["hugo@osrfoundation.org"]
    content = ('From: %s\r\nTo: %s\r\nSubject: %s\n\n%s'
                   % (fromaddr, ", ".join(toaddr_list), subject, text))
    server.sendmail(fromaddr, toaddr_list, content)
    server.quit()
finally:
    print("Done")


```

This is the new start_sim.bash

```
#!python

#!/bin/bash

/home/ubuntu/cloudsim/mail_ping.py router-10 "Simulation $1 $2 starting" &

# Just rename the old network usage file
sudo mv /tmp/vrc_netwatcher_usage.log /tmp/vrc_netwatcher_usage_`date | tr -d ' '`.log || true


# Stop the latency injection
sudo stop vrc_controller_private
sudo stop vrc_controller_public

# Restore the default tc rules
sudo vrc_init_tc.py bond0
sudo vrc_init_tc.py bond1

sudo iptables -F FORWARD
sudo stop vrc_netwatcher
kill -9 $(ps aux | grep vrc_netwatcher | awk '{print $2}') || true
sudo stop vrc_bytecounter
sudo start vrc_netwatcher
if ! ssh -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no -i ./key-sim.pem ubuntu@ "nohup bash cloudsim/start_sim.bash $1 $2 $3 > ssh_start_sim.out 2> ssh_start_sim.err < /dev/null"; then
  echo "[router start_sim.bash] simulator start_sim.bash returned non-zero"
  exit 1
fi

```
values.title: a script for the router that sends an email when a simulation is started

And an invocation in start_sim.bash (router side)

This is the mail script:

```
#!python
#!/usr/bin/python

#
# Send a mail to to drcsim-support@osrfoundation.com
# postfix should be installed on your system

try:

    import datetime

    _from = sys.argv[1]

    text = "at %s UTC" % datetime.datetime.utcnow()

    server.set_debuglevel(1)

    fromaddr = "%s@osrfoundation.org" % _from

                   % (fromaddr, ", ".join(toaddr_list), subject, text))
    server.sendmail(fromaddr, toaddr_list, content)
    server.quit()
finally:
    print("Done")


```

This is the new start_sim.bash

```
#!python

#!/bin/bash

/home/ubuntu/cloudsim/mail_ping.py router-10 "Simulation $1 $2 starting" &

# Just rename the old network usage file
sudo mv /tmp/vrc_netwatcher_usage.log /tmp/vrc_netwatcher_usage_`date | tr -d ' '`.log || true


# Stop the latency injection
sudo stop vrc_controller_private
sudo stop vrc_controller_public

# Restore the default tc rules
sudo vrc_init_tc.py bond0
sudo vrc_init_tc.py bond1

sudo iptables -F FORWARD
sudo stop vrc_netwatcher
kill -9 $(ps aux | grep vrc_netwatcher | awk '{print $2}') || true
sudo stop vrc_bytecounter
sudo start vrc_netwatcher
if ! ssh -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no -i ./key-sim.pem ubuntu@ "nohup bash cloudsim/start_sim.bash $1 $2 $3 > ssh_start_sim.out 2> ssh_start_sim.err < /dev/null"; then
  echo "[router start_sim.bash] simulator start_sim.bash returned non-zero"
  exit 1
fi
```

summary.html:
And an invocation in start_sim.bash (router side)

This is the mail script:

#!/usr/bin/python

#
# Send a mail to to drcsim-support@osrfoundation.com
# postfix should be installed on your system

try:
    import sys
    import smtplib
    import datetime

    _from = sys.argv[1]
    subject = sys.argv[2]

    text = "at %s UTC" % datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    server = smtplib.SMTP('localhost')
    server.set_debuglevel(1)

    fromaddr = "%s@osrfoundation.org" % _from
    toaddr_list = ["hugo@osrfoundation.org"]
    content = ('From: %s\r\nTo: %s\r\nSubject: %s\n\n%s'
                   % (fromaddr, ", ".join(toaddr_list), subject, text))
    server.sendmail(fromaddr, toaddr_list, content)
    server.quit()
finally:
    print("Done")

This is the new start_sim.bash

#!/bin/bash

/home/ubuntu/cloudsim/mail_ping.py router-10 "Simulation $1 $2 starting" &

# Just rename the old network usage file
sudo mv /tmp/vrc_netwatcher_usage.log /tmp/vrc_netwatcher_usage_`date | tr -d ' '`.log || true


# Stop the latency injection
sudo stop vrc_controller_private
sudo stop vrc_controller_public

# Restore the default tc rules
sudo vrc_init_tc.py bond0
sudo vrc_init_tc.py bond1

sudo iptables -F FORWARD
sudo stop vrc_netwatcher
kill -9 $(ps aux | grep vrc_netwatcher | awk '{print $2}') || true
sudo stop vrc_bytecounter
sudo start vrc_netwatcher
if ! ssh -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no -i ./key-sim.pem ubuntu@ "nohup bash cloudsim/start_sim.bash $1 $2 $3 > ssh_start_sim.out 2> ssh_start_sim.err < /dev/null"; then
  echo "[router start_sim.bash] simulator start_sim.bash returned non-zero"
  exit 1
fi

values.description:
This branch provides a set of Puppet manifests to setup an OpenStack cloud in a Vagrant virtual machine. Puppet manifests for preparing CloudSim are included too, which will serve as the basis for fully setting up CloudSim in a future branch.

You'll need Vagrant 1.2.3 and VirtualBox 4.2.16, please download them from http://vagrantup.com and https://www.virtualbox.org respectively. Heather (@hboortz) and I tested this branch on an Ubuntu 12.04 host.

Please have a look at the README.vagrant.md file, which includes instructions on how to start and manage the Vagrant machine, along with steps for setting up the network with VirtualBox.
values.title: Add support for setting up an OpenStack cloud via Vagrant

summary.raw:
This branch provides a set of Puppet manifests to setup an OpenStack cloud in a Vagrant virtual machine. Puppet manifests for preparing CloudSim are included too, which will serve as the basis for fully setting up CloudSim in a future branch.

You'll need Vagrant 1.2.3 and VirtualBox 4.2.16, please download them from http://vagrantup.com and https://www.virtualbox.org respectively. Heather (@hboortz) and I tested this branch on an Ubuntu 12.04 host.

Please have a look at the README.vagrant.md file, which includes instructions on how to start and manage the Vagrant machine, along with steps for setting up the network with VirtualBox.
summary.html:
This branch provides a set of Puppet manifests to setup an OpenStack cloud in a Vagrant virtual machine. Puppet manifests for preparing CloudSim are included too, which will serve as the basis for fully setting up CloudSim in a future branch.

You'll need Vagrant 1.2.3 and VirtualBox 4.2.16, please download them from http://vagrantup.com and https://www.virtualbox.org respectively. Heather (@hboortz) and I tested this branch on an Ubuntu 12.04 host.

Please have a look at the README.vagrant.md file, which includes instructions on how to start and manage the Vagrant machine, along with steps for setting up the network with VirtualBox.

This branch depends on the aws branch, so please merge it first before merging this one.

values.description:
This branch adds support for OpenStack to CloudSim using the AWS compatibility layer. It includes minor fixes for some scripts. ```create_cloudsim.py``` and ```cloudsim_bootstrap``` work again.

The instructions in the Gazebo wiki still apply to this branch, so AWS should be back. If you want to test OpenStack, you can do the following:

```shell
$ vagrant up
$ vagrant ssh

# Now you're inside the Vagrant VM

$ cd devstack
$ . eucarc admin
$ set|grep EC2 # this will print the EC2 credentials, you will have to copy them
$ logout

# Now you're on your machine

$ bin/create_cloudsim.py $EC2_ACCESS_KEY $EC_SECRET_KEY nova
```

The ```nova``` availability zone makes CloudSim use the OpenStack-specific code, but leaving it out will just run against the Amazon servers.

This branch depends on pull request #124, please merge that one before merging this.
values.title: Add support for OpenStack via the AWS layer

summary.raw:
This branch adds support for OpenStack to CloudSim using the AWS compatibility layer. It includes minor fixes for some scripts. ```create_cloudsim.py``` and ```cloudsim_bootstrap``` work again.

The instructions in the Gazebo wiki still apply to this branch, so AWS should be back. If you want to test OpenStack, you can do the following:

```shell
$ vagrant up
$ vagrant ssh

# Now you're inside the Vagrant VM

$ cd devstack
$ . eucarc admin
$ set|grep EC2 # this will print the EC2 credentials, you will have to copy them
$ logout

# Now you're on your machine

$ bin/create_cloudsim.py $EC2_ACCESS_KEY $EC_SECRET_KEY nova
```

The ```nova``` availability zone makes CloudSim use the OpenStack-specific code, but leaving it out will just run against the Amazon servers.

This branch depends on pull request #124, please merge that one before merging this.
summary.html:
This branch adds support for OpenStack to CloudSim using the AWS compatibility layer. It includes minor fixes for some scripts. create_cloudsim.py and cloudsim_bootstrap work again.

The instructions in the Gazebo wiki still apply to this branch, so AWS should be back. If you want to test OpenStack, you can do the following:

$ vagrant up
$ vagrant ssh

# Now you're inside the Vagrant VM

$ cd devstack
$ . eucarc admin
$ set|grep EC2 # this will print the EC2 credentials, you will have to copy them
$ logout

# Now you're on your machine

$ bin/create_cloudsim.py $EC2_ACCESS_KEY $EC_SECRET_KEY nova

The nova availability zone makes CloudSim use the OpenStack-specific code, but leaving it out will just run against the Amazon servers.

This branch depends on pull request #124, please merge that one before merging this.

values.description:
Related to issue #148.

The reason to remove this logic for now is that it adds a delay (currently 10 seconds) to the start of every simulator, without actually guaranteeing that logs get written out.  Better to not even bother trying to do the log-writing.
values.title: remove gz log cleanup logic

summary.raw:
Related to issue #148.

The reason to remove this logic for now is that it adds a delay (currently 10 seconds) to the start of every simulator, without actually guaranteeing that logs get written out.  Better to not even bother trying to do the log-writing.
summary.html:
Related to issue #148.

The reason to remove this logic for now is that it adds a delay (currently 10 seconds) to the start of every simulator, without actually guaranteeing that logs get written out. Better to not even bother trying to do the log-writing.

values.description:
The code that initializes the Redis data and creates the constellation directory to store the keys and credentials has been moved into launchers_utils.  
There, it will be accessible by create_cloudsim and unit tests that have no visibility on cloudsimd.py
